markdownRemark.html:
Score: 87.5

circa.com  (WEB - en-US)

A news site that originated as a smartphone application providing pithy stories and videos, which has expanded to include long-form articles.

This website generally maintains basic standards of credibility and transparency.
Does not repeatedly publish false content
Gathers and presents information responsibly
Regularly corrects or clarifies errors
Handles the difference between news and opinion responsibly
Avoids deceptive headlines
Website discloses ownership and financing
Clearly labels advertising
Reveals who's in charge, including any possible conflicts of interest
The site provides names of content creators, along with either contact or biographical information

Ownership or Financing

Circa is owned by Sinclair Broadcast Group Inc., a publicly traded company and one of the largest owners of local television stations in the U.S. Circa.com describes itself as Sinclair’s only national news and entertainment brand. The site generates revenue from advertising.

Content

Circa mostly publishes brief, 200-word stories designed to be quickly consumed, although it includes some longer-form pieces. Articles are frequently accompanied by videos, photos, tweets, and charts. Content covers U.S. and global news, lifestyle, food, technology, and entertainment. Some articles are original to Circa, while many come from Sinclair TV stations and The Associated Press.

Circa.com’s Watch section contains original video content, including news blurbs and longer features. ACirca Live section streams live content, when available.

Users can create accounts on the site and Circa’s mobile application to follow topics and contributors of interest, curating their feed based on their preferences.

Credibility

Original content features first-hand reporting and cites primary sources, to which stories frequently link. Circa articles reference reports from reputable news outlets such as ABC News and the BBC. Other stories are posted from established outlets including The Associated Press and local Sinclair stations. Headlines ares straightforward and factual.

Circa.com publishes corrections on stories it sources from other news outlets, but NewsGuard could not locate examples of corrections on original Circa content. The site did not respond to two NewsGuard emails asking about its corrections policy.

The site does not publish opinion pieces.

Liberal sites including the Guardian, the Daily Beast, and Media Matters have charged that since being acquired by Sinclair in 2015, Circa has gone easy on the Trump administration. A July 2017 Washington Post report said that Trump’s personal attorney, Marc E. Kasowitz, was hoping to use the site to counter negative stories about Donald Trump Jr.’s dealings with Russians during the 2016 presidential campaign. However, NewsGuard reviewed Circa’s coverage of President Trump and Donald Trump Jr., particularly its coverage of Trump Jr.’s involvement with Russia, and found that the site has been tough on both men.

Transparency

The site’s About page discloses its ownership by Sinclair and provides a form to submit general inquiries. Its Our Team page names its editors and reporters, providing biographies and social media contact information. Some stories name their author, while others are attributed to the news outlet that provided the original reporting. Advertisements are distinguished from editorial content.

History

Circa was founded in 2011 by Matt Galligan, founder of Socialthing and SimpleGeo; Ben Huh, founder of the Cheezburger network of sites; and Arsenio Santos, formelry a technologist at Digg and SonicLiving. Circa was created as a mobile app, then expanded to the web. Circa went on hiatus in 2015 until Sinclair Broadcast Group acquired the brand and relaunched the site in Spring 2016. 

Written by:
Sarah Brandt

Edited by:
Anna-Sophie Harling Eric Effron
